review.title: Twitter Sentiment Analysis
review.abstract: This project addresses the problem of sentiment analysis in twitter; that is classifying tweets according to the sentiment expressed in them: positive, negative or neutral. Twitter is an online micro-blogging and social-networking platform which allows users to write short status updates of maximum length 140 characters. It is a rapidly expanding service with over 200 million registered users - out of which 100 million are active users and half of them log on twitter on a daily basis - generating nearly 250 million tweets per day. Due to this large amount of usage we hope to achieve a reflection of public sentiment by analysing the sentiments expressed in the tweets. Analysing the public sentiment is important for many applications such as firms trying to find out the response of their products in the market, predicting political elections and predicting socioeconomic phenomena like stock exchange. The aim of this project is to develop a functional classifier for accurate and automatic sentiment classification of an unknown tweet stream.

sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text: Twitter is an online platform for microblogging and social networking that allows users to write short status updates up to 140 characters in length. It is a fast-growing service with over 200 million registered users [24] - of which 100 million are active users and half log on to Twitter daily - that generates almost 250 million tweets a day [20]. Due to this high level of usage, we hope that by analysing the feelings expressed in the tweets, we can achieve a reflection of the public mood. Public sentiment analysis is important for many applications, such as companies trying to find out the reaction of their products on the market, predict political elections and predict socio-economic phenomena such as the stock market. The aim of this project is to develop a functional classification for the accurate and automatic classification of the mood of an unknown tweet.Chapter 1 INTRODUCTION

sections.heading: Motivation
sections.text: The reason for this is that the amount of relevant data is much larger for Twitter than it is compared to traditional blogs. Furthermore, the response to Twitter is faster and also more general (since the number of users who write tweets is much higher than the number of those who write web blogs on a daily basis).The public sentiment analysis is extremely critical in terms of socioeconomic phenomena such as predicting the stock market rate of a particular company. This could be done by analyzing the general public sentiment towards that company in terms of time and using economic tools to find the correlation between public opinion and the stock market value of the company. Firms can also estimate how well their product reacts in the market, which areas of the market it has a beneficial response and where a negative reaction is possible (since twitter allows us to download streams of geo-tagged tweets for specific sites).

sections.heading: LITERATURE REVIEW
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Limitations of Prior Art
sections.text: Sentiment analysis in microblogging is a relatively new research topic, so there is a lot of room for further research in this area. A considerable amount of related previous work has already been done on sentiment analysis of user ratings [x], documents, web blogs / articles, and general phrase-level sentiment analyses [16], which differ from Twitter mainly because of the 140 character per tweet limit, which forces the user to compress his opinion in very short text. The best results in sentiment classification are achieved through monitored learning techniques such as Naive Bayes and Support Vector Machines, but the manual labeling required for the monitored approach is very costly.Some work has been done on unattended (e.g. [11] and [13]) and semi-monitored (e.g. [3] and [10]) approaches, and there is a lot of room for improvement. Various researchers who compare new features and classification techniques most efficiently, often compare their need for the same basic results with the fictitious ones.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that there is only one time that there is such a process, in which there is such a process.

This is one way to alleviate the state of independence and incorporate partial contexts into our word models, but is the use of bigrams and trigrams as well as the prior probability of these bigrams. Bigrams are a collection of two contiguous words in a text, and similar trigrams are collection of three contiguous words. Thus, we could determine the previous polarity of the bigrams and trigrams as well as the previous probability of these bigrams / trigrams belonging to a particular class - instead of the previous polarity of single words. Many researchers have experimented with them, when we have to use one of them alone, unigrams execute the best, while unigrams along with bigrams provide better results with certain classifiers. [2] Trigrams generally lead to poor performance as of pac reductions.

sections.heading: FUNCTIONALITY AND DESIGN
sections.text: The process of developing a functional classifier for mood analysis can be divided into five basic categories: I. Data Acquisition II. Human LabellingIII. Feature Extraction IV. Classification V. TweetMood Web Application

sections.heading: Data Acquisition:
sections.text: This API allows two ways of accessing tweets: • SampleStream and FilterStream. SampleStream simply delivers a small random sample of all tweets streamed in real time. FilterStream delivers tweets that meet a specific criterion. It can filter the tweets delivered according to three criteria: • Specific keyword (s) to track / search for tweets in the tweets. • Specific Twitter user (s) according to tweets coming from a specific location (s) where (geo-tagged tweets only) are flagged. The programmer can specify each of these filter criteria or a multiple combination of them. However, for our purpose we have no such restriction and therefore stick to the SampleStream fashion. As we wanted to increase the universality of our data, we acquired it at different times rather than acquire it.

sections.heading: Human Labelling:
sections.text: The reason why it has come to this is because most of the tweets we have sent are not because they are unable to have an effect, but because they are able to have an effect. "The reason why it has come to this point is because most tweets are not able to have an effect, but because they are able to have an effect." The reason why the tweets are not able to have an effect is in the way they are sent, in the way they are sent, in the way they are sent, in the way they are sent. "Most tweets are in the way they are sent, in the way they are sent, in the way they are sent."

sections.heading: Feature Extraction:
sections.text: Now that we have arrived at our training set, we need to extract useful features from it that can be used in the process of classification. • But first we will discuss some text formatting techniques that help us with feature extraction: • Tokenization: It is the process of splitting a text flow into tweets into words, symbols, and other meaningful elements known as "tokens." Tokens can be separated by whitespace characters and / or punctuation marks. It is done in such a way that we can consider tokens as individual components that transform a tweet into words, symbols, and other meaningful elements (identified by tokens "http" and "@"), ifwe are interested in analyzing only the text of the tweet.

sections.heading: Classification:
sections.text: The ultimate goal of our project is to design a classifier that divides tweets exactly into the following four sentiment classes: positive, negative, neutral and ambiguous tweets. There may be two types of sentiment classification in this area: Contextual sentiment analysis and general sentiment analysis. Contextual sentiment analysis deals with the classification of certain parts of a tweet according to the context provided, for example, for the tweet "4 more years of being in Shithole Australia then I move to the USA: D" a contextual sentiment classification would identify Australia with negative sentiment and USA with positive sentiment. On the other hand, general sentiment analysis deals with the general sentiment of the entire text (tweet in this case) as a whole. Thus, for the tweet already mentioned, as there is a general positive attitude, a precise general sentiment would identify general sentiment class.

sections.heading: TweetMood Web Application:
sections.text: We have designed a web application that performs real-time sentiment analysis on Twitter that matches specific keywords provided by the user. For example, if a user is interested in performing sentiment analysis on tweets containing the word "Obama," he / she will enter that keyword and the web application will perform the corresponding sentiment analysis and present the results to the user. The URL of the website is www.tweet-mood-check.appspot.com and its logo is stated below: The web application was implemented using the Google App Engine Service [21] because it can be used as a free web hosting service and provides the developer with a layer of abstraction from the low-level web operations, making it easier to learn. We implemented our algorithm in Python and integrated it with GUI for our website using HTML and Javascript using the jinja2 template [23] to easily understand the results of our visualization Google Chart.

sections.heading: TweetScore:
sections.text: This feature calculates the popularity value of the keyword, which is a number from 100 to -100. The more positive the popularity value, the more positive the keyword is on Twitter, while the more negative popularity value indicates that the keyword is very negatively popular on Twitter. A popularity value near 0 suggests that the keyword either has mixed opinions or is not a popular topic on Twitter. The popularity value depends on two ratios: • Number of positive classified tweets / Number of negative classified tweets • Number of purchased tweets / Time in the past required to get the REST APIThe first ratio suggests that the number of positive tweets is greater than the number of negative tweets to a particular keyword that the keyword would have the general opinion and vice versa. The second ratio suggests that the shorter time in the past we need to explore the REST API to get the 1,000 tweets means that more people are talking about the keyword on Twitter than the negative tweet, and thus the reverse is the case.

sections.heading: TweetCompare:
sections.text: This feature compares the popularity value of two or three different keywords and responds to which keyword is currently most popular on Twitter. This can have many interesting applications, for example, that our web application recommends users between movies, songs and products / brands.

sections.heading: TweetStats:
sections.text: This feature is for long-term mood analysis. We enter a number of popular keywords on Twitter on which a back-end operation runs after every hour, calculate the popularity value for the tweets generated with that keyword within a one-hour timeframe, and store the results against every hour in a database. We can have a maximum of 300 such keywords, according to Google's bandwidth requirements. So once we have a reasonable amount of data, we can use it to plot popularity value charts against time and visualize the effects of a changed popularity value in relation to specific events. Once we have gathered enough data, we can also use it to predict correlations with socio-economic phenomena such as stock markets and political elections. Tumasjan et al. [4] and Bollen et al. [9] have already worked on this.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION AND FUTURE RECOMMENDATIONS
sections.text: The task of sentiment analysis, especially in the field of micro-blogging, is still in the development phase and far from complete, so we propose a few ideas that we should explore for the future and that can lead to a further improvement in performance. At the moment, we have only worked with the simplest unigram models, but we can improve these models by adding additional information such as the proximity of the word with a negative word. We could specify a window in front of the word where, for example, it could be 2 or 3 words, the effects of negation can be included in the model if it is within this window. The nearest negative word is the unigram word whose previous polarity is to be calculated. It should affect polarity, if the negation is just next to the word to the right, it can simply reverse the polarity of the word and the negativity of the word is the negativity of the word from the word the word the negativity of the word.
